questions.explanation: Time delay by T multiplies the transform by e^(-sT). This exponential factor represents the phase shift that occurs when a signal is delayed. The magnitude |e^(-sT)| = 1, so only phase changes.
Multiplying by e^(at) in time shifts the transform by a to the right: X(s) → X(s-a). All poles and zeros shift right by a. This is dual to time shifting.
Differentiation multiplies by s and subtracts the initial condition: L{x'} = sX(s) - x(0-) = sX(s) - 3. The initial condition accounts for any energy stored before t=0.
Integration divides by s: L{∫x dt} = X(s)/s. This adds a pole at s=0. Integration is the inverse operation of differentiation, so division vs multiplication by s.
Convolution in time = multiplication in s-domain. This is the convolution theorem and why transfer functions are so useful: Y(s) = H(s)X(s). Simple multiplication instead of integration.

questions.prompt: Initial value x(0+) from X(s) is:
questions.explanation: Initial value theorem: x(0+) = lim(s→∞) of sX(s). This extracts the initial jump by looking at high-frequency (short-time) behavior. Works for all proper rational X(s).

options: All poles in LHP or at origin
questions.correctAnswer: All poles in LHP or at origin
questions.explanation: Final value theorem only works if the limit exists. sX(s) must have all poles in LHP (except possibly at s=0). RHP poles mean the system is unstable and has no finite final value.
Multiplication by t corresponds to negative differentiation with respect to s: L{tx(t)} = -dX(s)/ds. This is useful for finding transforms of t·e^(-at), t·sin(ωt), etc.
Start with L{cos(3t)u(t)} = s/(s²+9). The e^(-2t) factor shifts s→s+2: X(s) = (s+2)/((s+2)²+9). Frequency shift handles exponential multipliers.
Second derivative: L{x''} = s²X(s) - s·x(0-) - x'(0-) = s²X(s) - s - 2. Initial position contributes s-factor, initial velocity adds directly.
